paper.title: How past perceived portfolio returns affect financial behaviors-The underlying psychological mechanism
paper.abstract: The study proposes and tests the underlying psychological mechanisms on how investors' past perceived portfolio returns affect their trading and risk taking, and if these psychological mechanisms are significant mediators. Using a covariance based structural equation modeling and multiple mediation tests with a dataset of Malaysian retail investors, the results show that: (a) In line with the naive reinforcement learning, hot-hand fallacy and representativeness heuristics, investors' excessive extrapolation of past perceived portfolio returns causes them to display optimism, overconfidence and risky attitude; (b) these psychological biases, in turn, lead to portfolio turnover, trading intention, risky share holding and willingness of risk taking; and (c) overconfidence, optimism and risk attitude emerged as multiple mediators. The results lead to the conclusion that the presence of underlying biases deteriorates financial behaviors.

domain_result.justification: 该论文研究了投资者过去感知的投资组合回报如何影响其交易和风险承担行为，并探讨了这些行为对投资组合周转率、风险资产持有等的影响，这直接关联到投资组合管理的核心问题。
